docs.lead_paragraph: Without so much as a nick to her scalp, Cheryl Hogarth had major brain surgery on a tumor that had grown to nearly the size of a Ping-Pong ball deep within her brain. Ms. Hogarth, who at 37 was told her malignant tumor was inoperable and given a prognosis of six months to live, went under the Gamma Knife, no-knife surgery that blasts its target with hundreds of high-intensity radiation beams in a single session. There was none of the cutting, bleeding, general anesthesia, ear-to-ear scar or long recovery associated with traditional craniotomy. She went home that evening.

headline.main: Brain Surgery, Without Knife or Blood, Gains Favor

docs.abstract: Radiosurgery, which was used for nearly 10 percent of brain operations in 1999, is explained and, in particular, use of Gamma Knife radiosurgery is compared with traditional neurosurgery; Dr Dade Lunsford, chief neurosurgeon of first North American Gamma Knife center at University of Pittsburgh, and investor in Electa, maker of Gamma knife, contends 60% of all metastatic brain tumors could be controlled by radiosurgery, but estimates only 10% receive treatment; lack of long term data has fueled debate between surgeons favoring open craniotomy and those using radiosurgery, but evidence from widespread and decades-old radiosurgeries on acoustic neuromas shows recurrence rates similar for each proceedure; obstacles to and exclusionary circumstances involving radiosurgery are detailed; diagram; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Without so much as a nick to her scalp, Cheryl Hogarth had major brain surgery on a tumor that had grown to nearly the size of a Ping-Pong ball deep within her brain.    Ms. Hogarth, who at 37 was told her malignant tumor was inoperable and given a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Using sunscreen daily reduces the risk of skin lesions that are associated with skin cancer, Australian researchers have found. Writing in this month's issue of The Archives of Dermatology, the researchers said that regular, liberal use of sunscreen ''can play a strong role in minimizing'' the development of the lesions, known as solar keratoses. Skin cancer is 3 to 12 times more likely to occur in the presence of the lesions.
docs.abstract: Archives of Dermatology publishes study, led by Dr Steven Darlington of Queensland Institute of Medical Research (Australia), that shows 24% decrease in skin lesions when people apply sunscreen daily, thereby reducing skin cancer, which is more likely to occur when lesions are present; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Using sunscreen daily reduces the risk of skin lesions that are associated with skin cancer, Australian researchers have found.    Writing in this month's issue of The Archives of Dermatology, the researchers said that regular, liberal use of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Our only child was born seven years ago with a rare birth defect requiring multiple surgeries and three months in neonatal intensive care. When Max turned 4 and trotted off to preschool clutching a plastic dinosaur, I returned to the hospital as a nursery volunteer.

headline.main: A Family Gone AWOL And a Baby Gone Awry

docs.abstract: Cases article discusses emotional and physical complications of dealing with and responsibility for babies born with birth defects; recounts experiences dealing with baby born after under 24 weeks with many disabilities; baby was not visited or cared for by his family during many months of hospital care; subsequent emotional toll on volunteers and staff members discussed (M)
docs.snippet: Our only child was born seven years ago with a rare birth defect requiring multiple surgeries and three months in neonatal intensive care.    When Max turned 4 and trotted off to preschool clutching a plastic dinosaur, I returned to the hospital as a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Statins, used by millions of people with high cholesterol levels, may also have potential as a medication for Alzheimer's disease, a new study reports. The drugs appear to reduce brain cholesterol, which plays a role in the formation of plaques that interrupt brain function in people with Alzheimer's. The study, led by Dr. Gloria Lena Vega of the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, appears in this month's Archives of Neurology.
docs.abstract: Texas University Southwestern Medical Center Dr Gloria Lena Vega publishes study in Archives of Neurology that indentifies possible link between use of statins, often prescribed for high cholesterol, and potential benefits in reducing brain cholesterol, which is essential to production of plaques that effect Alzheimer's disease; more research is needed to determine if statin therapy can prevent or slow disease; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Statins, used by millions of people with high cholesterol levels, may also have potential as a medication for Alzheimer's disease, a new study reports.    The drugs appear to reduce brain cholesterol, which plays a role in the formation of plaques...

docs.lead_paragraph: What really distinguishes man from beast? Well, it's nothing as lofty as the philosophers would have us believe. Forget about theory of mind, morality or even the culinary arts. It's much simpler: the capacity to make a mess. After all, what other animal species can boast of slobs -- or neat freaks for that matter -- among its ranks? Even the famously filthy pig is quite a clean creature. And one would be hard-pressed to find a breed of dog that makes a mess of its den.

headline.main: Forget Oscar and Felix: Messiness Is No Laughing Matter

docs.abstract: Behavioral aspects of messiness, such as age, psychiatric conditions and most commonly, ability to overlook chaotic environment because of spatial unawareness, are discussed; messiness, although annoying to parents and partners alike, does not generally seem to signify mental disorganization or inhibit most people's creativity or productivity; however, obsessive-compulsive disorder can often manifest itself in hoarding, eventually causing cluttered environment and shift in individual environment as people age, from order to disorder, can be sign to onset of disease such as Alzheimer's; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What really distinguishes man from beast? Well, it's nothing as lofty as the philosophers would have us believe. Forget about theory of mind, morality or even the culinary arts. It's much simpler: the capacity to make a mess.    After all, what other...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A Matter of Dignity: Changing the Lives of the Disabled,'' by Andrew Potok. Bantam Books, $24.95. Some 50 million Americans have serious disabilities, and while the lives of many have improved considerably, 70 percent of them are unemployed. A vast majority can work and want to, writes the author of this look into the world of the disabled, but the presumption that they will be a burden and the ''disincentive of losing health insurance'' often prevent them from doing so.
docs.abstract: Blind artist and author Andrew Potok has written Matter of Dignity: Changing Lives of Disabled; book chronicles lives of those who have made strides toward integrating and empowering disabled individuals; Potok hopes book will inspire others to help transform lives and improve system that does not credit disabled people with being able to contribute to their community and workplace; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adam B. Kaufman, 29, describes his skin as a ''personal hell'' that leaves him in unrelenting pain. ''Have you ever put on one of those facial masks and let it harden?'' said Mr. Kaufman, an actor from New York. ''That's how I feel. It hurts to move my face, and my eyes are close to swollen shut.''

headline.main: When Life in Your Own Skin Is Agony

docs.abstract: Article on Adam B Kaufman, who suffers from most severe form of eczema known as atopic dermatitis, which has, until recently, had very few treatment options for those afflicted; condition causes red, itchy, scaly and inflamed skin that during flare-ups produces weeping or crusting sores; alternative therapies and steroid creams relieve symptoms to some degree, but new drugs Eladil and ProTopic are now FDA-approved and give better relief from pain and itching, although they do not cure condition; Dr Lawrence Kutner, Harvard Medical School Center for Mental Health co-director, emphasizes need for doctors to address psychological effects of ailment in conjunction with physical effects; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies who share a bed with their mothers tend to have higher sleeping heart rates than other babies, scientists have found, but the cause -- and any possible implications -- are unclear. The report was presented recently at an experimental biology conference in San Diego sponsored by the American Physiological Society. The research was done at the University of California at Irvine by Dr. Christopher A. Richard and Dr. Sarah S. Mosko.
docs.abstract: University of California (Irvine) Drs Christopher A Richard and Sarah S Mosko research, presented at American Physiological Society meeting, finds babies have slightly elevated sleeping heart rate when they share bed with Mom; reason for rise is not identified; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Babies who share a bed with their mothers tend to have higher sleeping heart rates than other babies, scientists have found, but the cause -- and any possible implications -- are unclear.    The report was presented recently at an experimental...

docs.lead_paragraph: Too much sedentary behavior -- and especially television watching -- puts people at higher risk for obesity and diabetes, a new study reports. Writing last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers calculated that for every two hours a day spent watching television, there is a 23 percent increase in obesity and a 14 percent increase in the risk of type 2 diabetes.
docs.abstract: Harvard School of Public Health Dr Frank B Hu publishes study in Journal of American Medical Association that shows people who watch more than average amount of TV increase risk of obesity and diabetes; article cites lower metabolic rate in those who watch TV than in others who are reading or playing board games and individual's propensity to eat while watching; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Too much sedentary behavior -- and especially television watching -- puts people at higher risk for obesity and diabetes, a new study reports.    Writing last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers calculated that for...

docs.lead_paragraph: David Bloom was a talented and intrepid journalist. He died just shy of his 40th birthday while covering the war in Iraq for NBC. He died seemingly suddenly, but not from hostile or friendly fire. Rather, a pulmonary embolism, a blood clot that lodged in the artery to his lungs, shut off the oxygen supply to his heart. The clot started in a vein deep in his leg (deep vein thrombosis) and is believed to have resulted from sleeping night after night cramped up in a military tank recovery vehicle.

headline.main: Patients on Anticlotting Drug Face a Tricky Balancing Act

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column focuses on unfortunate death of journalist David Bloom in Iraq and aspects of drug warfarin that might have saved him from pulmonary embolism; warfarin requires careful monitoring to maintain delicate balance between thinning blood enough to contol clotting, but not so much as to cause excess bleeding; precautions one can take to avoid blood clots are given; photo (M)
